questions.text: Which of the following is not Ménière’s disease?
questions.solution:
Ménière’s disease is also called endolymphatic hydrops.

It is a disorder of the inner ear where the endolymphatic system is distended with endolymph. This occurs due either due to excessive production or faulty absorption of endolymph.

It has 2 variants:

  • Cochlear hydrops - the main feature is hearing loss. Vertigo is absent.
  • Vestibular hydrops - repeated episodes of vertigo without loss of hearing.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about Ménière’s disease?
  1. Has a constant course
  2. Sensorineural type of hearing loss
  3. Usually affects the age group of 35-60 years
  4. Usually a unilateral condition
  5. Conductive type of hearing loss
questions.solution:
Ménière’s disease is commonly seen in the age group of 35-60 years and incidence peaks in the fifth decade.  It is a disorder of the inner ear causing a sensorineural type of hearing loss. Usually, it is unilateral but the other ear may be affected after a few years.

Symptoms of the disease occur in attacks (episodes) and there is not a constant presence of the symptoms.

questions.text: Which of these symptoms is least likely to be present in a patient diagnosed with Ménière’s disease?
questions.solution:
Otalgia is least likely to be present in a patient diagnosed with Ménière’s disease.

The characteristic triad of Ménière’s disease includes:

  1. Episodic vertigo- attacks come in clusters, with periods of spontaneous remission lasting for weeks, months, or years
  2. Fluctuating hearing loss- hearing is affected during episodes of vertigo, improves after the attack, and maybe normal during remissions
  3. Tinnitus- low-pitched whistling or roaring type

Warning symptoms preceding an attack of vertigo in Ménière’s:

  • Sense of fullness in the ear
  • Change in pitch or increasing intensity of tinnitus
  • Decrease in hearing

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with complaints of intolerance to loud sounds and mild giddiness associated with ringing in the ear. What is the probable cause of intolerance to loud sounds in this patient?
questions.solution:
Intolerance to loud sounds in this patient is due to the recruitment phenomenon (sound is amplified to be heard better). It is a feature of all cochlear pathologies.

The characteristic presentation of a middle-aged man with vertigo, tinnitus, and intolerance to loud sounds points to a diagnosis of Ménière’s disease. It is a cochlear pathology, hence shows the recruitment phenomenon.

The rollover phenomenon is a feature of retro-cochlear pathologies like an acoustic neuroma.

Diplacusis is the perception of a single auditory stimulus as sounds of a different pitch in two ears.

Tullio phenomenon is a condition where loud sounds precipitate a vertiginous attack.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented with a history of vertigo, tinnitus, and intolerance to loud sounds. He constantly gets vertiginous episodes when exposed to loud sounds or noise. This phenomenon is not seen in which of the following conditions?

choices.text: ASOM with a perforated tympanic membrane

questions.solution:
The phenomenon described above is the Tullio phenomenon and is not seen in ASOM with a perforated tympanic membrane. 

The Tullio phenomenon refers to sound-induced vertigo. People with this condition experience unsteadiness, vertigo, nausea and rapid involuntary eye movements (nystagmus) when exposed to loud sounds or noise. It is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

Some cases of Ménière’s disease show the Tullio phenomenon.

It is also seen whenever there is a third mobile window lesion such as otic syphilis, perilymph fistula and dehiscence of semicircular canals.

questions.text: Which of the following would be the most likely audiometric finding in a patient who is diagnosed with early Ménière’s disease?
questions.solution:
Early Ménière’s disease affects lower frequencies. As the disease progresses, all the frequencies become affected.

There is no classical audiogram pattern that can be used to identify Ménière’s disease. However, there are certain features that have been commonly observed. These include:

  • A varying degree of sensorineural hearing loss.
  • This hearing loss is usually low frequency.

questions.text: What is the summating potential: action potential ratio seen in Ménière’s disease on electrocochleography?
questions.solution:
Summating potential: action potential ratio (SP: AP) >0.4 or 0.5 are consistent with a diagnosis of Ménière’s disease. 

Normally, the ratio of SP to AP is 0.3 (suggestive of normal cochlear function).

questions.text: A middle-aged patient presented with a history of recurrent episodes of whirling vertigo, which usually are preceded by a variable sense of ear pressure and fullness, decreased hearing, and low-tone roaring tinnitus. Which of the following is a useful test to diagnose this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history points to a diagnosis of Ménière’s disease. The glycerol test is useful for the diagnosis of Ménière’s disease.

Glycerol is an osmotic diuretic which when given orally reduces hydrops and improves symptoms. Electrocochleography done along with a glycerol test. An improvement after administration of glycerol is diagnostic of Ménière’s disease.

The caloric test used in Ménière’s disease is not diagnostic as it is abnormal in many other conditions like ototoxicity, vestibular schwannoma, vestibular neuritis, etc.

Dix-Hallpike test is performed to diagnose BPPV. A positive test would result in a vertiginous episode and nystagmus observed by the clinician.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presented with a history of progressive hearing loss over a year, followed by an episode of sudden onset vertigo. He noticed an improvement in hearing after the vertiginous episode. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis would be Lermoyez syndrome. 

It is a variant of Ménière’s wherein the symptoms appear in reverse order. The patient presents with a progressive hearing loss followed by an attack of vertigo which causes improvement in hearing.

Lemierre’s syndrome is a condition characterized by infectious thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein and bacteremia caused by primarily anaerobic organisms, following a recent oropharyngeal infection. 

Leriche syndrome, commonly referred to as an aortoiliac occlusive disease, is due to thrombotic occlusion of the abdominal aorta just above the site of its bifurcation.

Leigh syndrome (subacute necrotizing encephalomyelopathy) is a rare genetic neurometabolic disorder characterized by degeneration of the CNS.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with Meniere’s disease presented with a history of sudden fall without loss of consciousness and no associated neurological or cardiovascular symptoms. On examination, there were no neurological deficits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis.

Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis (drop attacks) is when a patient with Meniere’s develops sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness. It is an uncommon manifestation. Its pathogenesis is not well understood.

Tullio phenomenon: It is a condition seen with some cases of Meniere's disease, where loud sounds or noise produce vertigo. This phenomenon is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

Lermoyez syndrome: Here symptoms of Meniere's disease are seen in reverse order. Initially, there is a progressive deterioration of hearing, followed by an attack of vertigo.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a differential diagnosis for a patient with suspected Ménière’s disease?
questions.solution:
CSOM is a middle ear disease with symptoms of ear discharge and is not a differential for Ménière’s.

Ménière’s is a cochlear pathology with symptoms of vertigo, hearing loss & tinnitus.

Differentials of Ménière’s disease:

  • Vestibular neuronitis
  • BPPV
  • Cervical spondylosis
  • Acoustic tumours
  • Vertebrobasilar insufficiency
  • Labyrinthitis
  • Perilymph fistula
  • Migraine induced vertigo

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman diagnosed with Ménière’s disease presented with complaints of sudden onset dizziness and sensation of surroundings swirling. Which of the following drugs cannot be used as a vestibular sedative to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Among the given drugs, Loratadine is not a vestibular sedative.

Loratadine is a second generation antihistamine which lacks CNS depressant effects. It is used for allergic rhinitis, chronic idiopathic urticaria, and exercise-induced bronchospasm prophylaxis.

The first line of treatment of an acute episode of Ménière’s is symptomatic and hence vestibular sedatives are the mainstay in the treatment. These are

  • Dimenhydrinate
  • Prochlorperazine
  • Promethazine
  • Rarely- diazepam and atropine

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is a vasodilator of the inner ear?
questions.solution:
Betahistine is a vasodilator of the inner ear. It is used in the treatment of Meniere's disease.

It is reported to act by:

  • Improving microvascular circulation in the stria vascularis of the cochlea
  • Inhibiting vestibular nuclei activity

questions.text: An ENT surgeon is going to perform a chemical labyrinthectomy on a patient with Meniere's disease, that is refractory to treatment. Which of the following drugs will he be using for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Gentamicin is the drug used in chemical labyrinthectomy.

Gentamicin is mainly vestibulotoxic. It has been used in daily or biweekly injections into the middle ear (Intratympanic gentamicin therapy). The drug is absorbed through the round window and destroys the vestibular labyrinth.

questions.text:
Microwick and microcatheter devices are used in which of the following diseases?
  1. Otosclerosis
  2. Meniere’s disease
  3. CSOM
  4. Sudden sensorineural hearing loss
  5. Autoimmune cochlear disease
questions.solution:
Microwick and microcatheter devices are used to treat Meniere’s disease, sudden sensorineural hearing loss (sudden SNHL), and autoimmune inner ear disease. 

These devices are used to deliver drugs from the external canal to the inner ear thereby avoiding repeated intratympanic injections. When soaked with the drug, wick delivers it to the round window to be absorbed into the inner ear. It has been used to deliver :

  • Steroids in sudden sensorineural deafness and autoimmune inner ear disease.

  • Gentamicin to destroy the vestibular labyrinth in Ménière’s disease.

questions.text: A patient with Meniere’s disease has debilitating vertigo episodes which are causing him multiple daily falls. On examination, mild hearing loss is present. Which of the following is not a treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Labyrinthectomy is a destructive procedure that totally destroys cochlear and vestibular function. Thus, It is used only when the cochlear function is not serviceable. This patient has mild hearing loss with disabling vertigo, so conservative procedures are to be offered. In these procedures, hearing is preserved.

Conservative procedures done for Ménière’s include:

  • Decompression of endolymphatic sac
  • Endolymphatic shunt operation
  • Sacculotomy (Fick’s operation)
  • Section of the vestibular nerve
  • Ultrasonic destruction of vestibular labyrinth.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman is on treatment for Ménière’s disease for two years. Unfortunately, there is no improvement in her symptoms despite taking medications and intratympanic gentamicin injections. Which of the following treatment modalities would you not recommend for her?
questions.solution:
A vestibulectomy is not done in Ménière’s disease. It is a surgical procedure that can be used to treat vulvar pain, specifically in cases of provoked vestibulodynia.

Ménière’s disease, unresponsive or refractory to medical management (including intratympanic gentamicin) is treated with surgery. They can either be:

  • Conservative (hearing is preserved):
    • Decompression of endolymphatic sac
    • Fick’s Sacculotomy
    • Endolymphatic shunt
    • Vestibular neurectomy
    • Ultrasonic destruction of the vestibule
  • Destructive: Labyrinthectomy
  • Meniett’s device- provides intermittent positive pressure to the inner ear which improves hearing and reduces vertigo in these patients

questions.text: What is the definitive treatment of intractable vertigo due to Meniere’s disease?
questions.solution:
The definitive treatment of intractable vertigo due to Ménière’s disease is labyrinthectomy. 

Labyrinthectomy involves uniform destruction of hearing and vestibular function. Ideal candidates have no functional hearing and have failed more conservative treatments, such as gentamicin injection. Despite this morbidity, labyrinthectomy has the highest rate of vertigo control (>95%), more than vestibular neurectomy (78-90%), and is considered the single definitive treatment.

The step-by-step management approach for Ménière's disease consists of dietary modifications and vestibular suppressants as the initial measures, followed by intratympanic gentamicin ablation, and finally, surgical intervention.

Primarily, the management of Menier's disease involves a sodium restricted diet and diuretics like acetazolamide (Option A). They are more useful for short-term control. 

Gentamicin (Option D) is a selective vestibulotoxic aminoglycoside antibiotic that is preferentially taken up by type I hair cells. It is opted for only if dietary modifications and vestibular suppressants have failed to control the symptoms. If used judiciously, hearing is preserved.

The options for surgical management include - Endolymphatic sac surgery, vestibular neurectomy, and labyrinthectomy. Endolymphatic sac surgery is currently declining in popularity due to lack of evidence of vertigo control. 

Vestibular neurectomy (Option C) refers to selective ablation of the vestibular nerve. Even though it is considered a hearing sparing surgery and carries comparable rates of vertigo control as labyrinthectomy, it is an intradural procedure and carries a greater risk of complications. Hearing loss will still progress as it would have in the natural course of illness.

questions.text: Which of the following features is not associated with superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome?
questions.solution:
Sensorineural hearing loss is not seen in superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome (SSCDS). They may experience mild to moderate hearing conductive loss.

Conductive hearing loss is due to the abnormal transmission and dissipation of acoustic energy through the defect (third window), leading to reduced conduction to the cochlea for lower frequencies. This can manifest as a low-frequency air-bone gap at multiple frequencies. There is no defect in the cochlea or the auditory pathway.

Superior semicircular canal dehiscence (SSCD) is a condition in which bone between the apex of the superior semicircular canal and the middle cranial fossa is absent. This causes endolymph in the labyrinthine system to move with sound or pressure, causing an activation of the vestibular system. 

Patients may have vestibular symptoms like vertigo triggered by loud sounds (Tullio phenomenon)or pressure such as coughing and can also experience hyperacusis for bone-conducted sounds. They may perceive the sounds of their own eye movements or footsteps in the affected ear. 

The patients may exhibit nystagmus when exposed to loud sounds or during the Valsalva maneuver or pressure in the ear canal (positive fistula test). The direction of the nystagmus aligns with the affected superior semicircular canal, and some patients may tilt their heads in the plane of the affected superior semicircular canal in response to loud sounds.  

Noncontrast HRCT of the temporal bone can demonstrate the defect. The click-evoked VEMP (vestibular evoked myogenic potential) response and vestibuloocular reflex are pronounced in SSCD patients, in which the evoked eye movements align with the affected superior canal. 

For mild symptoms, avoidance of triggers is recommended. In case of severe disabling symptoms, surgical resurfacing of the superior semicircular canal or plugging of the superior semicircular canal may be attempted.

questions.text: A patient complains that he feels like the room is spinning when he gets up from lying down or turning his head. He has no history of loss of consciousness. Which of the following could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, with complaints of dizziness associated with postural change and no history of loss of consciousness is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).

BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal.

A positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis of BPPV. In this maneuver, the patient begins sitting up with their head turned 45 degrees toward the ear to be tested. Then the patient is made to lie down quickly with their head past the end of the bed. Then, the patient's neck is extended 20 degrees below the horizontal. The clinician then watches the patient's eyes for torsional and up-beating nystagmus, which should persist for no more than one minute. This would indicate a positive test.

Epley's maneuver is performed to reposition the crystals into the macula from the semicircular canals. This is only a temporary cure and there is a high rate of recurrence.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the ENT surgeon with a history of vertigo whenever she moves sideways on the bed while lying supine. She feels nauseous and as if the room is spinning. The symptoms subside after a few minutes but return when she moves her head. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The diagnostic maneuver used in BPPV is the Dix-Hallpike maneuver, the gold standard for diagnosing BPPV. The therapeutic maneuver is Epley's maneuver.

BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal.

A patient presenting with vertigo should be evaluated for ruling out the central lesions (like a tumor in the fourth ventricle, multiple sclerosis, etc) before confirming the diagnosis of BPPV. Dix-Hallpike maneuver helps rule out central lesions and also diagnose BPPV.

Dix-Hallpike maneuver:

  1. The maneuver starts with the patient in a sitting position.
  2. Their head is turned 45 degrees towards the ear to be tested.
  3. The examiner quickly brings the patient to a supine position with their head 30 degrees below the horizontal.
  4. The 45-degree head rotation is maintained during the procedure.
  5. Now the examiner observes the patient for nystagmus.
